author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Mauricio Lima
title: After Fire Razes Squalid Greek Camp, Homeless Migrants Fear What’s Next
description: The camp, already a bleak emblem of Europe’s migrant policy, was locked down after a coronavirus outbreak, prompting some asylum seekers to set fires that left thousands homeless.
content: LESBOS, Greece — They’ve been sleeping on tombstones and on the side of the road, in parking lots and among dried weeds on the hillsides. They’ve pitched makeshift tents with bamboo poles and blankets. They’ve used the few clothes they have to make mattresses so their babies don’t sleep on tarmac.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Poniewozik
title: Review: ‘We Are Who We Are’ Captures Not-So-Innocents Abroad
description: Luca Guadagnino’s HBO series is a heady teen drama of hormones and self-discovery on a U.S. Army base in Italy.
content: The supermarket at the U.S. Army base in Chioggia, Italy, looks as if it could be anywhere in the world. That’s exactly the point. As Britney (Francesca Scorsese), a teen living on base, explains it to new kid Fraser (Jack Dylan Grazer), all the military stores like it are precisely alike, down to the same items in the same places in the same aisles. “So we don’t get lost,” she says.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin and Judith Levitt
title: Wildfires, 2020 Election, N.F.L. Sunday: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Hoffman, Ben Shpigel, Ken Belson, Elena Bergeron and Gillian R. Brassil
title: N.F.L. Week 1: Live Updates From Opening Sunday
description: The Saints won the Brees-Brady showdown; the Patriots won their first game with Cam Newton at quarterback; and the 49ers lost a tight battle with the Cardinals.
content: The 49ers quarterback Jimmy Garoppolo ended the last N.F.L. season missing Emmanuel Sanders on a deep throw over the middle in the Super Bowl. He began this one operating an impotent offense that scored 10 points across its final nine possessions and converted 2 of 11 third-down chances.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Should the SALT Cap on Deductions Be Repealed?
description: Readers discuss who benefits and who is harmed by the $10,000 cap on deductions for state and local taxes, and whether progressives should back the repeal.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger, David McCabe and Erin Griffith
title: Oracle Chosen as TikTok’s Tech Partner, as Microsoft’s Bid Is Rejected
description: The moves came as the clock ticks down on President Trump’s executive order to block the Chinese-owned social media app.
content: WASHINGTON — The Chinese owner of TikTok has chosen Oracle to be the app’s technology partner for its U.S. operations and has rejected an acquisition offer from Microsoft, according to Microsoft officials and other people involved in the negotiations, as time runs out on an executive order from President Trump threatening to ban the popular app unless its American operations are sold.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca R. Ruiz
title: Bloomberg Says He’ll Spend $100 Million in Florida to Help Biden
description: The move came as polls show a tight race in Florida, and after criticism that the New York billionaire had not delivered on his promise to put his fortune behind defeating President Trump.
content: Michael R. Bloomberg, the former New York City mayor and presidential candidate, announced Sunday that he planned to spend $100 million in Florida in the coming weeks to support Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s presidential candidacy.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Sunday Read: ‘The Children in the Shadows’
description: More than 100,000 of New York City’s public school students lack permanent housing. They are caught in bureaucratic limbo that often seems like a trap.
content: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Astead W. Herndon
title: Minnesota Seemed Ripe for a Trump Breakout. It Has Not Arrived.
description: Minnesota was a near miss for Donald Trump in 2016. But new polling shows him well behind where he finished four years ago in a state he views as a prime pickup opportunity.
content: DULUTH, Minn. — For a campaign event featuring Donald Trump Jr., the brash-talking, liberal-dunking namesake of the president, it was all rather mundane.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Sunday, Sept. 13, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Sept. 13, 2020
content: The Markets Last Week chart last Sunday misstated the percentage decline of the price of Apple Inc. stock over the previous week, and erroneously included Apple on a list of that period’s worst-performing stocks. The shares fell 3.1 percent — not 75.8 percent, a figure that failed to take into account the company’s four-to-one stock split.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Schram
title: Stars Are One Win Away From Winning the West
description: Anton Khudobin made 32 saves, including stops during a 5-on-3 penalty kill in the third period, in Dallas’s 2-1 win over the Vegas Golden Knights.
content: EDMONTON — Unlike many of the behemoth goaltenders in the modern N.H.L., the Dallas Stars’ Anton Khudobin checks in at just 5 feet 11 inches and 195 pounds. But the 34-year-old has stood tall between the pipes this summer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melena Ryzik
title: A Violinist Lost His Seat and His Job. He Blames China.
description: In a lawsuit filed in New Jersey, a former member of the well-known Shanghai Quartet said he had been dumped after a remark he made on social media was misinterpreted as an ethnic slur.
content: Yi-Wen Jiang, a violinist who was, until recently, billed as a member of the Shanghai Quartet, an internationally known chamber group with roots in China, says he didn’t give the pig emoji a second thought.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Levin and Kate Taylor
title: As Fires Disrupt Schools, ‘the Pandemic Has Actually Helped’
description: After wildfires consumed an entire town, students and teachers who had planned for remote classes found some comfort in staying connected amid the chaos.
content: Ash fell from an apocalyptic orange sky as Jennifer Willin drove home last week from the only school in tiny Berry Creek, Calif., where she had picked up a pair of Wi-Fi hot spots for her daughters’ remote classes. Hours later, her cellphone erupted with an emergency alert: Evacuate immediately.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Cubs’ Alec Mills Throws a No-Hitter Against the Brewers
description: It was the 16th no-hitter in Chicago franchise history and the second in Major League Baseball this season.
content: MILWAUKEE — From college walk-on to major league starter, the Chicago Cubs right-hander Alec Mills had to earn most every break he got.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Motoko Rich and Hisako Ueno
title: Shinzo Abe Vowed Japan Would Help Women ‘Shine.’ They’re Still Waiting.
description: Female workers remain largely shut out of management jobs, and many take part-time work because of overwhelming family responsibilities, despite policies that Mr. Abe said would elevate their standing in society.
content: TOKYO — This was supposed to be the era when Japan finally stepped beyond its centuries of patriarchal dominance and empowered women in the workplace. Prime Minister Shinzo Abe said the country’s prosperity depended on it, and promised policies to help women “shine.” He even gave the push a name: womenomics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David M. Halbfinger
title: In Arab States’ Embrace, Israelis See a Reshaped Mideast
description: Normalized ties with the United Arab Emirates and Bahrain raise hopes in Israel that it is finally gaining acceptance in its volatile neighborhood.
content: JERUSALEM — Since its founding, Israel has seen itself as a modern-day Sparta, a tiny fortress nation-state in a hostile desert, whose survival depended on its internal cohesion and sheer military strength.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bonnie Wertheim
title: Florence Howe, ‘Mother of Women’s Studies,’ Dies at 91
description: In 1970, she helped found the Feminist Press. It was hailed for making available “a legacy of writings by and about women.”
content: Florence Howe, a key architect of the women’s studies movement and a founder of the Feminist Press, a literary nonprofit dedicated to promoting social justice and amplifying overlooked voices, died on Saturday in Manhattan. She was 91.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: New York City Council, Don’t Roll Back Police Reforms
description: Officials might weaken a law that bans chokeholds and other police maneuvers that restrict airflow.
content: In June, as New York City was gripped by protests over the death of George Floyd, the City Council passed legislation banning police officers from using maneuvers that restrict a person’s airflow. Now the Council, cowed by pressure from police unions and officials, is considering rolling back part of this important step toward police accountability.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: N.F.L. Kicks Off Season With Nods to Unrest and Focus on Anthem
description: Several teams stayed in the locker room for the pregame playing of the national anthem, while some players knelt during it or wore decals and shirts against hate and racism.
content: Two N.F.L. teams locked arms and knelt. A star quarterback wore cleats bearing the message “No Justice No Peace.” The phrase “End Racism” was stenciled on the field, which many players avoided during the playing of the national anthem.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Mandela. Dalai Lama. Gorbachev. Now Trump?
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, September 13, 2020.
content: “First of all, icicles in hell come to mind. Ain’t gonna happen.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Comes Out Ahead
description: John Guzzetta opens our solving week.
content: MONDAY PUZZLE — When we last saw John Guzzetta, he was pulling no punches with a tough Saturday puzzle, but this time he’s opening our solving week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Kliff
title: How My 2-Year-Old Planted a Coronavirus Story Idea
description: After another child at my son’s day care tested positive, I ran into obstacle after obstacle trying to get him a test. I quickly learned I wasn’t alone among concerned parents of young children.
content: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri and Lauren Hard
title: 2 Killed, 6 Injured in Shooting Near Rutgers University
description: Video obtained by The New York Times shows four men arriving at the scene in a car and shooting into the area.
content: Two people were killed and six others wounded in a shooting early on Sunday morning that took place blocks away from the Rutgers University campus in New Brunswick, N.J., the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes That Sold for Under $500,000
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
content: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Week
description: The weather is just starting to turn in some parts of the country. It’s time for the most comforting of stews.
content: Good morning. The weather’s turning where I stay, the close, soft mornings giving way to a little bite, low-pressure fog lingering longer over the bays. Not for me the morning orange and cold glass of coffee I used to love, not these days. My taste runs to eggs, fried soft on a warm tortilla, a steaming cup of tea beside it. It’s time to bulk up. Autumn’s coming, and winter hard behind it.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Trump Holds Indoor Rally as White House Officials Try to Defend His Virus Response
description: Infections in Britain have spiked back up to levels not seen in months. After a fire razed a refugee camp in Greece, homeless migrants fear what’s next.
content: President Trump on Sunday held a campaign rally indoors for the first time since late June, when he appeared at an event in Tulsa, Okla., that was later blamed for a surge in coronavirus cases in the area. The rally on Sunday night, held at a manufacturing plant outside Las Vegas in defiance of a state directive limiting indoor gatherings to under 50 people, was attended by thousands of the president’s supporters, the vast majority of whom did not wear masks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert M. Marovich
title: 50 Years Ago, They Did Something Rare in Gospel: Tied Music to Protest
description: The Voices of East Harlem went from community stages to the Isle of Wight Festival, blending the soul-cleansing power of Christian songs with R&B, funk and rock on “Right On Be Free.”
content: The graphic video montage of violence against people of color that accompanies Isaac Cates & Ordained’s sobering neo-spiritual “Hold On” brought the hosts of the 2020 online music festival Vox Virtual nearly to tears. Lydia Salett Dudley commissioned a clip with similarly vivid imagery for “Whatcha Gonna Say?,” a funky song released this summer that commands listeners to speak out about inequality or face the consequences of inaction today and in the afterlife.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Nechepurenko and Andrew Higgins
title: Embattled Belarus Leader Beset by More Protests Before Putin Summit
description: President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko has for weeks tried to quell protests against his re-election claim. A day before meeting President Vladimir V. Putin, his main backer, he continued to crack down on the opposition.
content: MINSK, Belarus — A day before high-stakes talks in Russia, President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko, the embattled strongman leader of Belarus, deployed his security forces in large numbers to deter ongoing protests. But tens of thousands of people still took to the street on Sunday to once again clamor for his resignation.
source.name: The New York Times

title: It’s New York Fashion Week, Live
description: From New York, this week you can watch new shows by Jason Wu, Rebecca Minkoff, Chromat and more.
content: Right now, New York Fashion Week is on. But the age of front rows and crowded shows is somewhat on hold; we can bring all of fashion week to you right here. Coming soon!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: When Good People Don’t Act, Evil Reigns
description: Stop thinking that the horrors of the world will simply work themselves out.
content: I have often wondered how major world tragedies and horrors were allowed to unfold. Where were all the good people, those who objected or should have? How did life simply go on with a horror in their midst?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: For Victoria Azarenka, Disappointment Again, but Plenty of Hope
description: Unseeded coming into the U.S. Open and far removed from a time when she was at the top of the women’s game, Azarenka showed how dangerous she could be. Will it stick?
content: For Victoria Azarenka, a surprise United States Open run began to unravel in the seventh game of the second set, the 14th game of a Saturday afternoon final that had been nearly perfect for her from the start.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlotte Cowles
title: The Week in Business: Let’s Call the Whole Thing Off
description: In a bad week for deals, a new aid bill fizzled in Congress and Tiffany’s sale fell apart.
content: Hi everyone. Here’s your quick catch-up on the latest news in business and tech, plus what you need to know for the week ahead. — Charlotte Cowles
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roni Caryn Rabin
title: The Maitre d’ Will Take Your Temperature Now
description: Fever checks are becoming de rigueur in many workplaces and restaurants, even though federal health officials say they are of limited value.
content: In recent weeks, a new cadre of gatekeepers armed with thermometer guns has appeared at the entrances of hospitals, office buildings and manufacturing plants to screen out feverish individuals who may carry the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: Review: City Dancers Unleashed in the Wild
description: Our critic reveled in the fact that the only thing separating him from BalletCollective performers was the late-summer air.
content: PINE PLAINS, N.Y. — The Mashomack Fish & Game Preserve Club, a few hours’ drive north of New York City, is not the natural habitat of dancers, at least not of members of New York City Ballet and the Martha Graham Dance Company. But this is where I observed them participating in the normal behavior of their species: performing live.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Turkewitz
title: Colombia Sees Surge in Mass Killings Despite Historic Peace Deal
description: “It is not easy to protect the whole population,” the country’s high commissioner for peace said in an interview.
content: They were 20-somethings at a party after months of pandemic-related quarantine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gillian R. Brassil
title: Josh Allen Tops 300 Yards Passing as Bills Beat Jets in Opener
description: Fans often argue about which quarterback is better — the Jets’ Sam Darnold or the Bills’ Josh Allen. The season opener provided some answers.
content: Without fans in the stands, the Jets and the Buffalo Bills apparently decided to do what they usually do — only bigger.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bhadra Sharma
title: Dozens Feared Dead as Nepal Landslides Wipe Out Homes
description: Many in the region had only just rebuilt homes that were damaged by a powerful 2015 earthquake. The country is also facing an economic crisis brought on by the coronavirus pandemic.
content: KATHMANDU, Nepal — Landslides set off by heavy rainfall this weekend killed at least 11 people and left many more missing in a hilly region of Nepal that borders Tibet, officials said, bringing a renewed crisis to an area that was hit hard by a devastating 2015 earthquake.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti, Stephanie Saul and Patricia Mazzei
title: Big Voting Decisions in Florida, Wisconsin, Texas: What They Mean for November
description: Less than two months before the election, both parties are waging legal battles around the country over who gets to vote and how.
content: As Democrats and Republicans prepare to fight for votes in the fall general election, recent court decisions in three battleground states illustrate how each side is maneuvering for the best possible legal position to achieve its goals — with Democrats hoping to expand voting to as many citizens as possible and Republicans working to limit it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Sept. 14, 2020
description: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
content: Students
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allyson Waller and Marie Fazio
title: California Deputies Shot in Ambush Are Expected to Recover, Authorities Say
description: The Los Angeles County deputies were critically injured after being fired upon in their car outside a Metro station in Compton. The gunman remained at large, the authorities said.
content: Two deputy sheriffs who were shot multiple times as they sat in a parked patrol car in Los Angeles on Saturday evening are expected to recover from their injuries, the authorities said Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Rosenberg
title: Retired Colonel Criticizes ‘Solitary Confinement’ of Quarantined Soldiers at Guantánamo
description: Eric Kerska, whose daughter was deployed to the base, said he was alarmed by the isolation of young soldiers on their first tour as a coronavirus precaution.
content: This article was produced in partnership with the Pulitzer Center on Crisis Reporting.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘I Was Enjoying Dinner Alone on My Favorite Boulder in St. Nicholas Park’
description: A quiet place on a summer evening, a taste of wine and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chelsea Brasted, Melina Delkic and Marie Fazio
title: In New Orleans, Recovering From One Storm and Preparing For Another
description: Tropical Storm Sally is the latest Gulf storm that seems likely to hit Louisiana as a hurricane this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Fuller and Jack Healy
title: As Wildfires Burn Out of Control, the West Coast Faces the Unimaginable
description: Firefighters across California and Oregon are bracing for stronger winds that could partly clear the air — but also fan the flames of uncontrolled blazes.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — Across a hellish landscape of smoke and ash, authorities in Oregon, California and Washington State battled to contain mega-wildfires on Sunday as shifting winds threatened to accelerate blazes that have burned an unimaginable swath of land across the West.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Gutierrez
title: U.S. Marine Pardoned for Killing Transgender Woman Is Deported From Philippines
description: Lance Cpl. Joseph Scott Pemberton was formally deported and flown out on a U.S. military plane. His pardon by President Rodrigo Duterte has drawn anger from activists.
content: MANILA — A U.S. Marine who received a pardon from President Rodrigo Duterte for the killing of a transgender woman was deported from the Philippines on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: Feminists Paper Paris With Stark Posters Decrying Domestic Abuse
description: A widespread but illegal campaign by a group calling itself “the Gluers” uses posters to denounce violence against women. It has become an effective — and ubiquitous — tool to raise awareness.
content: PARIS — On a recent mild night, a squad of four young women wandered through a peaceful neighborhood in eastern Paris, armed with a bucket of glue, a paintbrush and backpacks loaded with posters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: Israel to Celebrate Jewish New Year Under a Second Lockdown
description: Citizens will be confined to within 500 yards of their homes for at least three weeks in an effort to contain the spread of coronavirus.
content: JERUSALEM — Israel is heading back into a nationwide lockdown for at least three weeks starting on Friday, the eve of the Jewish New Year holiday, in the clearest sign yet of the government’s failure to contain the spread of the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chang W. Lee
title: Empty Seats, Slowly Filled With Energy
description: A photographer’s account of covering a U.S. Open unlike any that had come before it.
content: It was depressing. My first United States Open match this year was the men’s doubles final, with Mate Pavic and Bruno Soares playing Wesley Koolhof and Nikola Mektic at Arthur Ashe Stadium. It was supposed to rain, so the roof of the stadium was covered. It was humid, dark, and the resonating noise of machines never stopped. But most of all, the seats were largely empty.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Decoupling From China: There’s Precedent
description: A former U.S. trade negotiator says Japan, India and Australia have already taken steps. Also: Kenosha, my hometown; making the switch to metric.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Schaverien
title: Trial Is Postponed of British-Iranian Woman Held in Iran
description: Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe is already serving time after being accused of plotting to overthrow Iran’s government. The case has further strained fraught ties between Britain and Iran.
content: A new trial in Iran to present fresh charges against a British-Iranian woman who has been held in the country since 2016 was postponed at the last minute on Sunday, her husband said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Becky Ferreira
title: How Old Is This Ancient Vision of the Stars?
description: It’s a tale of bronze, iron, looting and archaeological conflict.
content: The Nebra sky disk has been hailed as the oldest known representation of the cosmos. Uncovered by looters in 1999 and then recovered in a sting by archaeologists and law enforcement a few years later, the ancient bronze artifact, inlaid with gold decorations of the night sky, has provoked heated debates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By George A. Hirsch
title: It Was 50 Years Ago Today, the Marathon Came to New York to Stay
description: There won’t be a New York City Marathon this year, but we can celebrate the anniversary of the first one, held on Sept. 13, 1970.
content: Many sports fans assume the New York City Marathon has always occurred in October or early November, and always run through the five boroughs. That’s not the case. Indeed, the first New York City Marathon took place entirely within Central Park, and it happened 50 years ago, on Sunday, Sept. 13, 1970.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Phillips
title: Review: Four Intimate Screen Encounters (One From Far Away)
description: The second grouping of these excellent “Here We Are” monologues includes a raucous report from outer space and a small gem from Lynn Nottage.
content: On the night I watched several of the short plays that make up “Here We Are,” I was at my laptop in the living room while one roommate cooked dinner in the kitchen, just a few feet away, and my other roommate shuffled in and out, doing laundry. Behind me, on the other side of our bay windows, the sounds of Brooklyn wafted in from the street: people chatting, cars going by, dogs barking.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes and Pranshu Verma
title: At U.S.A.I.D., Juggling Political Priorities and Pandemic Response
description: Aggressive oversight of the aid agency by political appointees at the White House and the State Department has delayed humanitarian aid when the world needs it most.
content: WASHINGTON — The coronavirus was spreading around the world, and officials at the United States Agency for International Development were anxious to rush humanitarian aid to nations in need. But first, they had to settle a debate over American branding and whether it should be displayed on assistance headed to conflict zones.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Eisenhower Memorial, Delayed by Design Disputes, Opens This Week
description: The memorial in Washington, D.C., pays tribute to the general who led the Allies to victory in Europe during World War II and the president who sought peace after it was over.
content: WASHINGTON — At a time when statues and memorials are being taken down or reconsidered across the United States, a new one is going up in the nation’s capital that could shape the roiling debate over how the country chooses icons to honor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Gendler
title: 2020 U.S. Open: Men’s Final Preview
description: Dominic Thiem and Alexander Zverev will play in the men’s singles final of the United States Open on Saturday.
content: How to watch: Starting at 4 p.m. Eastern time on ESPN in the United States; and streaming on the ESPN app.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear and Coral Davenport
title: In Visiting a Charred California, Trump Confronts a Scientific Reality He Denies
description: A president who has mocked climate change and pushed policies that accelerate it is set to be briefed on the scorched earth and ash-filled skies that experts say are the predictable result.
content: WASHINGTON — When President Trump flies to California on Monday to assess the state’s raging forest fires, he will come face to face with the grim consequences of a reality he has stubbornly refused to accept: the devastating effects of a warming planet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carole Landry
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: Japan’s new leader, North Korea, Afghan talks: Here’s what you need to know.
content: As the Japanese prime minister ends his nearly eight-year run in office, one of the unfulfilled aspirations of his tenure is promoting women in the work force. Mr. Abe had found a name for his effort, “womenomics,” but many Japanese women say he did not go much beyond the slogan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Schoenfeld Walker and Lisa Waananen Jones
title: Conflicting Virus Data in Texas Raises Distrust of the Government
description: Delays, discrepancies and abrupt leaps in coronavirus case and death counts in Texas have baffled residents and frustrated local officials. Here is what has gone awry.
content: Inconsistencies and problems with Covid-19 data collection in Texas have clouded the picture of the pandemic’s trajectory in the state, to the point that some residents and officials say they cannot rely on the numbers to tell them what is really going on.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ellen Barry
title: How Kamala Harris’s Immigrant Parents Found a Home, and Each Other, in a Black Study Group
description: Donald Harris and Shyamala Gopalan grew up under British colonial rule on different sides of the planet. They were each drawn to Berkeley, and became part of an intellectual circle that shaped the rest of their lives.
content: At an off-campus space at the University of California at Berkeley in the fall of 1962, a tall, thin Jamaican Ph.D. student addressed a small crowd, drawing parallels between his native country and the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Williams
title: A New Look at the Often Barely United States
description: Richard Kreitner talks about “Break It Up,” his new book about deep divisions and secessionist movements throughout American history.
content: In “Break It Up,” his new book about the history of deep divisions and secessionist movements in the United States, Richard Kreitner recalls Hillary Clinton’s concession speech in 2016, when she said that the country must be “more deeply divided than we thought.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Greed Is Good. Except When It’s Bad.
description: Fifty years ago today, Milton Friedman published a seminal essay that is still hotly debated in business and policy circles.
content: Sept. 13 is an important date in the world of business. Fifty years ago on that day — today — Milton Friedman published a seminal essay in The New York Times Magazine that is still hotly debated in business and policy circles. DealBook teamed up with The Times Magazine to revisit the legacy of the so-called Friedman Doctrine in a special issue out today in print. This newsletter runs through some of the highlights, along with bonus material and other features to mark the occasion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Rothenberg
title: At U.S. Open Wheelchair Finals, Players Are Glad the Events Were Held at All
description: The wheelchair tournaments were initially canceled before a backlash from players prompted the United States Tennis Association to change its mind.
content: When the United States Open announced its plans in June for this year’s tournament, it included the elimination of the junior draws, the singles qualifying draws and the mixed doubles draws because of the coronavirus pandemic. But perhaps the biggest outcry came from the smallest contingent of the tournament: the men and women in the wheelchair divisions.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘It Is Apocalyptic’: Fear and Destruction Grip the West Coast
description: President Trump will fly to California on Monday to assess the wildfires that have killed at least 24 people. In hard-hit Oregon, officials have warned that the death toll could climb.
content: This briefing has ended. Read the latest on the West Coast wildfires.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Thomas
title: Vaccine Makers Keep Safety Details Quiet, Alarming Scientists
description: Researchers say drug companies need to be more open about how vaccine trials are run to reassure Americans who are skittish about getting a coronavirus vaccine.
content: The morning after the world learned that a closely watched clinical trial of a coronavirus vaccine had been halted last week over safety concerns, the company’s chief executive disclosed that a person given the vaccine had experienced serious neurological symptoms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allyson Waller and Aimee Ortiz
title: Georgia Sheriff’s Deputy Is Fired Over Beating of Black Man
description: The Clayton County Sheriff’s Office said the deputy was terminated for “excessive use of force” after a video showing him pinning and punching Roderick Walker, 26, was circulated widely on social media.
content: A sheriff’s deputy in Georgia has been fired after video circulated on social media showing him pinning and beating a Black man after a traffic stop, the authorities said on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elena Bergeron
title: What to Know About N.F.L. Week 1
description: Some familiar faces joined new teams — looking at you, Tom Brady and Cam Newton — and young stars like Lamar Jackson are ready to pick up where they left off in a season unlike any other.
content: It’s going to be weird to watch football on Sunday, in a year where any flash of sports normalcy happens amid countless off-field calamities. The dissonance of playing football right now was on display on Thursday night, with excitement over the resumption of the N.F.L.’s rituals tempered in Kansas City, where Patrick Mahomes and the Chiefs were booed by a reduced-capacity crowd for standing in solidarity with the Houston Texans before the game and then cheered for clobbering them during it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Phoebe Lett
title: 4 Podcasts to Help Heal Your Mind
description: Use this playlist to learn more about mental health and to understand your own better.
content: In trying times, sorting through your thoughts and emotions can be hard. If you are looking for help, there is no substitute for professional treatment and medical intervention. A self-care podcast may provide supplemental support. There are many programs that guide audiences through meditations, take them into psychologists’ offices or share conversations with experts on mental well-being. These four shows might help you reflect on your feelings or simply provide insights about mental health and the human psyche you didn’t know before.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Will Wright, Mitch Smith and Lazaro Gamio
title: New Cases Have Reached Record Levels in the Midwest
description: As new coronavirus cases have dropped nationally, infections have soared in the Midwest.
content: As new coronavirus cases have dropped nationally, infections have soared in the Midwest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press and Reuters
title: West Coast Wildfires Burn More Than 4 Million Acres
description: More than 20 people have died in massive fires spreading through parts of California, Oregon and Washington.
content: More than 20 people have died in massive fires spreading through parts of California, Oregon and Washington.
source.name: The New York Times
